stem: The nurse in the intensive care unit is reviewing serial ABG results for a client with septic shock. Based on the documentation in the ABG Trend Analysis, match the current lab profile with its correct interpretation.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00: Client (58y/o male) admitted with septic shock. BP is low (88/52) and lactate is elevated. 
09:00: Client started on norepinephrine and aggressive fluid resuscitation. 
10:30: Client's respiratory rate has increased to 32/min as he attempts to compensate for metabolic acidosis. 
12:00: Follow-up ABG shows an improving pH but a very low PaCO2.

tabs.title: ABG Trend Analysis
tabs.content:
TimepHPaCO2HCO3Interpretation
08:007.244214Uncompensated Metabolic Acidosis
10:307.313014Partially Compensated Met Acidosis
14:007.422818Fully Compensated Met Acidosis

rationale.correct: At 08:00 (r1), the pH is low and the CO2 is normal, indicating no attempts at compensation yet (Uncompensated). By 10:30 (r2), the pH is still low but the CO2 has dropped significantly as the lungs 'blow off' acid; since the pH isn't normal yet, it is **Partially Compensated**. By 14:00 (r3), the pH is now in the normal range (7.42) because of the continued respiratory effort; this is **Fully Compensated**.
clinicalPearls: Partial Compensation: All 3 values (pH, CO2, HCO3) are abnormal.
Full Compensation: pH is normal, but CO2 and HCO3 are both abnormal reflecting the 'battle' to stay balanced.
The 'Lungs' are the fast compensators (minutes/hours), 'Kidneys' are slow (days).

questionTrap.trap: Believing that a 'normal' pH means there is no acid-base problem.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always check the CO2 and HCO3. If they are abnormal but the pH is normal, you have a fully compensated imbalance!

mnemonic.title: Compensation Check
mnemonic.expansion: Full = pH is Happy (Normal). Partial = pH is still Mad (Abnormal).
